awd_titl_txt: Discovering Modular Catalysts for Asymmetric Synthesis with Computation
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Robert Paton of the Department of Chemistry at Colorado State University is supported by an award from the Chemical Catalysis program in the Division of Chemistry to develop new computational approaches for chiral catalyst discovery. The preparation of chiral molecules plays a vital and enabling role in the discovery of medicines, agrochemicals, and materials. Newly approved drugs are dominated by single enantiomer, chiral compounds. Dr. Paton’s group develops new methods of theory and simulation to accelerate the discovery of new catalysts and new reactions for the highly-selective construction of chiral molecules. This will go hand-in-hand with new mechanistic discoveries and collaborations with experimentalists that broaden the horizons of participating scientists. The research team, which will include undergraduate and postgraduate researchers, will learn a diverse array of skills well-aligned with the modern STEM workplace and will engage the public through outreach events in Colorado.

There is a widely recognized need for rational approaches to replace empirical screening in the discovery of new catalyst structures. In this project, Dr. Robert Paton is developing computational protocols that combine small-molecule fragments adhering to the synthetic logic of known coupling reactions to construct and optimize catalyst architectures for asymmetric transformations. Virtual catalyst libraries are being assembled and mapped in an automated fashion using computational chemistry descriptions of steric and electronic properties. A triaged approach is being developed that directs in-depth quantum chemical efforts towards the most profitable areas of catalyst space to promote enantioselective hydrogen-bonding phase-transfer catalysis, bifunctional organocatalysis, and transformations involving metal-phosphoramidite complexes. In each case, new mechanistic discoveries are revealing the structural pre-requisites for catalytic activity and high enantioselectivity for a given substrate. The automated construction of large catalyst libraries, and the computation of steric and electronic parameters are providing that large datasets of use to the broader community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. We developed new computational workflows and automation tools to enable chemists to study the mechanisms and selectivities of catalytic reactions. These studies have produced new automation software, new chemical insights, and have directly contributed to the discovery of new homogeneous catalytic reactions. Through a combination of quantum mechanical calculations with new workflows, we have been able to make complex, multi-step investigations more accessible and reproducible.

Mechanistic explorations of phase transfer catalysis involving hydrogen-bond donors enabled us to develop quantitative structure-selectivity relationships to relate catalyst structures with experimental outcomes, such as enantioselectivity and regioselectivity. Theory-led approaches have also allowed us to explore the stability and chemistry of oxonium ions, resulting in the design of new chiral molecules for which the sole stereogenic center is an oxygen atom.

We have built a comprehensive understanding of the reactivity and enantioselectivity of nucleophiles when bound to chiral H-bond donating phase-transfer catalysts. Correlations between nucleophile charge and regioselectivity, can now be applied predictively to control the site-selectivity of nucleophilic additions. Computations have illustrated how the control of nucleophile binding through three-point binding modes are essential for achieving enantioselectivity in this important class of transformation.

 

Broader Impact The research team working on this project at Colorado State University has involved multiple graduate and undergradate students. These students have received a broad base of training in computational and organic chemistry, and they have developed coding skills relevant to software and workflow development. Multiple projects have been carried out in collaboration with experimentalists, which has also provided an interdisciplinary research environment for training and professional development. Several project personnel have progressed to computational chemistry and informatics positions in the STEM workforce, and to graduate research positions at other universities, following participation in this project.

 


Last Modified: 09/22/2024
Modified by: Robert S Paton
